cip.render.raytrace.interfaces

Interface IRtGeometry

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    IRtGroup
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AGeometry, AQuadricGeo, Cone, Cylinder, Ellipsoid, Hyperboloid, HyperParaboloid, Paraboloid, PlanarPolyhedra, Sphere, XfmGeometry

    public interface IRtGeometry
    This is the interface for geometry that can be ray-traced. The assumptions are that any object that can be ray-traced is a valid closed non-self-intersecting solid. This means that if a ray goes into the object, it can always be traced out of the object, and it won't report the ray going into itself again before it goes out.
    Since:
    1.0

    • Method Detail

      • getType

        @NotNull
@NotNull java.lang.String getType()
        Get the geometry type. Useful in error logging or messaging.
        Returns:
        (not null)

      • initSampling

        void initSampling(int nSample,
                  float[] f1dSample,
                  float[] f1dRandom,
                  Point2f[] pt2dSample,
                  Point2f[] pt2dRandom,
                  Point3f[] pt3dSample,
                  Point3f[] pt3dRandom)
        Specifies the sampling arrays that should be used for distributed ray-tracing. Geometries that do not participate in distributed ray-tracing will normally ignore this function, or, pass the arrays down to child geometries which may make use of the sampling arrays. Normally, these are used for motion-blurr in animated objects.
        Parameters:
        nSample - The number of subsamples (oversamples) per pixel.
        f1dSample - The 1d sample displacement array. The length of this array will be equal to the number of subsamples per pixel. This array is for oversampling linear phenomena.
        f1dRandom - The 1d 'jitter' array. No assumptions should be made about the length of this array.
        pt2dSample - The 2d sample displacement array. The length of this array will be equal to the number of subsamples per pixel. This array is for oversampling area phenomena.
        pt2dRandom - The 2d 'jitter' array. No assumptions should be made about the length of this array.
        pt3dSample - The 3d sample displacement array. The length of this array will be equal to the number of subsamples per pixel. This array is for oversampling volume phenomena.
        pt3dRandom - The 3d 'jitter' array. No assumptions should be made about the length of this array.

      • isConvex

        boolean isConvex()
        Reports whether the solid is convex or not. If there is any question about convexity, the object should return false to the query.

        The convexity query is used to determine whether an object needs to tested for self-shadowing or self-reflection, and possibly for othe optimizations in the ray tracing process. If an object reports it is not convex, it will always render correctly though there may be unnecessary processing if the object actually is convex. If an object incorrectly reports that it is convex, ther will likely be errors in shadow and reflection computations for that object.

        Returns:
        Returns true if the object is convex and false if the object is not convex or the convexity cannot be verified.

      • isInside

        boolean isInside(Point3f pt)
        Tests whether a point is inside ot outside the geometry. This might be interesting, for example, for a travelling camera that ystal ball.
        Parameters:
        pt - (readonly) The point to be tested.
        Returns:
        true if the point is inside the geometry, false otherwise.

      • getConvexHullVertices

        Point3f[] getConvexHullVertices()
        Returns the vertices of the convex hull for the object. There are no limits to the number of vertices that define the convex hull for the object. A tighter convex hull generally means a better fitting bounding volume after transformation.
        Returns:
        Returns the array of convex hull vertices, Returns null if a convex hull cannot be fit to the object. Being unable to fit a convex hull implies that the object must be explicitly queried for intersection on every ray. The returned array should be a copy of anything stored locally in the object and it must be OK if this array is subsequently modified by the caller.

      • getBvIntersection

        boolean getBvIntersection(Bv3fIntersection bvInt,
                          Line3f ray)
        Tests the bounding volume of the object for intersection. If the object does not have a bounding volume it should true and set the bounding volume intersection to indicate there was an intersection with the ray originating inside the bounding volume, entering the bounding volume at Float.NEGATIVE_INFINITY and leaving the bounding volume at Float.POSITIVE_INFINITY.
        Parameters:
        bvInt - The bounding volume intersection.
        ray - The ray being tested for intersection with the bounding volume.
        Returns:
        true if the ray intersects the bounding volume and may intersect the object, false if the ray does not intersect the bounding volume and cannot intersect the object.

      • getRayIntersection

        boolean getRayIntersection(@NotNull
                           @NotNull RayIntersection intersection,
                           @NotNull
                           @NotNull Line3f ray,
                           boolean bStartsInside,
                           int nSample,
                           int nRandom)
        Test for an intersection with the ray. Return true and update the RayIntersection if this is a closer intersection than what is currently in the RayIntersection, otherwise return false and leave the intersection unchanged. When an object reports that it has a closer intersection, the object MUST fill in the RayIntersection.m_fDist, RayIntersection.m_pt, RayIntersection.m_vNormal, RayIntersection.m_ptObject, RayIntersection.m_vObjNormal, RayIntersection.m_xfmObjToWorldNormal, RayIntersection.m_mtl, RayIntersection.m_rtObj. The object may choose to fill in the natural coordinates of the intersection, in which case RayIntersection.m_bNatural should be set to true though it is most common for objects to set this to false and not go through the expense of computing natural coordinates unless they are specifically requested later in the rendering process.
        Parameters:
        intersection - (RayIntersection, not null, modified) The intersection of the ray and the surface. The intersection will be either freshly initialized or will contain information about the closest intersection discovered thus far. It will be updated for this intersection if it is a closer intersection.
        ray - (Line3f, not null, readonly) The ray being tested for intersection.
        bStartsInside - false if this is an outside ray, true if this is a ray spawned from an intersection with this object and on the inside of the object.
        nSample - The pixel sub-sample index. This is used in distributed ray-tracing to make sure the correct sample displacement is used for samples that are distributed.
        nRandom - The jitter array index.
        Returns:
        Returns true if there is an intersection with this object that is closer than the current intersection, and false otherwise.

      • getNaturalCoordinates

        void getNaturalCoordinates(RayIntersection intersection)
        Get the natural coordinates that are associated with the object-space intersection point. When called, an object should use the object coordinates intersection set in the intersection to generate the natural coordinates which are filled into the RayIntersection.m_ptNatural, and RayIntersection.m_vNatural fields of the intersection. Additionally, the RayIntersection.m_bNatural flag should be set to true to prevent redundant computation of natural coordinates. If the RayIntersection.m_bNatural flag is already true then the natural coordinates for the intersection have already been computed and the function can immediately return.
        Parameters:
        intersection - The ray intersection.

      • testShadow

        boolean testShadow(RayIntersection intersection,
                   Vector3f vLight,
                   float fDistLight,
                   IRtLight light,
                   int nSample,
                   int nRandom)
        Test whether there is an intersection with the ray from the intersection in the vLight direction that is closer than the distance to the light, fDistLight. Return true of there is an intersection- which means that there is something between the intersection and the light and this object casts a shadow on the intersection.
        Parameters:
        intersection - The intersection being tested for shadow.
        vLight - The direction from the intersection to the light.
        fDistLight - The disance from the intersection to the light.
        light - The light. This is supplied as an argument in the event an object is both a light source and a geometry and the geometry of the light should not be tested for casting a shadow from that light.
        nSample - The pixel sub-sample index. This is used in distributed ray-tracing to make sure the correct sample displacement is used for samples that are distributed.
        nRandom - The jitter array index.
        Returns:
        Returns true if this object casts a shadow from the light and false otherwise.
